Literature Review: Single-molecule tracking (SMT) and imaging techniques have revolutionized the field of molecular biology by enabling the observation of individual biomolecules in real-time and under physiological conditions. This capability has provided unprecedented insights into the dynamics and mechanisms of biological processes at the molecular level. The development of SMT techniques began in the early 1990s, with significant advancements in fluorescence microscopy and detection technologies allowing for the visualization of single molecules in solution at room temperature (Moerner and Kador, 1989). Since then, the field has seen rapid progress, with the introduction of various methods to track and image single molecules in three-dimensional (3D) environments, offering ultrahigh spatiotemporal resolution and sufficient working depths for complex biological systems (Shen et al., 2017). One of the key advancements in SMT is the development of feedback-control tracking systems, which dynamically adjust the microscope's focus to follow the movement of single molecules in real-time, enabling long-term observation over seconds to minutes (Cang et al., 2013). This technique has been instrumental in studying the dynamic behavior of biomolecules in their native environments, revealing distinct pathways and roles in downstream signaling. Another significant innovation is point-spread-function (PSF) engineering, which modifies the shape of the PSF to encode spatial information, allowing for precise 3D localization of single molecules (Pavani et al., 2009). This method has been particularly useful in tracking molecules within thick tissues and complex cellular structures. Multiple plane microscopy (MPM) has also emerged as a powerful tool for 3D SMT, capturing images at different focal planes simultaneously to reconstruct the 3D trajectory of single molecules (Juette et al., 2008). This approach has enabled researchers to study the spatial and temporal dynamics of biomolecules in 3D tissue models, providing insights into their functional roles in supporting life. The trajectory data obtained from SMT experiments contain valuable information about the dynamics and interactions of single molecules. Advanced trajectory analysis methods have been developed to extract observables such as diffusion coefficients, binding kinetics, and interaction networks (Manzo and Garcia-Parajo, 2015). These analyses have revealed the heterogeneity and complexity of molecular behaviors, challenging the traditional view of biological processes as homogeneous and deterministic. Single-molecule clustering analysis has further enhanced our understanding of molecular organization and function, identifying spatial patterns and functional domains within cells (Lillemeier et al., 2010). Despite the remarkable progress in SMT and imaging techniques, challenges remain in achieving higher resolution, longer tracking durations, and the ability to study molecules in more complex and dynamic environments. Future directions in the field include the integration of SMT with other imaging modalities, the development of new fluorescent probes and labeling strategies, and the application of machine learning algorithms for data analysis (Liu et al., 2015). These advancements will continue to push the boundaries of single-molecule research, offering new opportunities to unravel the complexities of biological systems at the molecular level.
